answers.answer: Hi there.  Metformin is often used for PCOS.  While it is a drug for diabetes, it has been found to be effective for women with PCOS.  That's why they probably put you on this medication rather than the idea you may develop diabetes down the road.  Many women use metformin with PCOS and I've read that this helps increase their likelihood of conceiving!  (good news for you since you'd like a baby).The issue with PCOS and women trying to conceive is that as you mentioned, they have very irregular periods and ovulation doesn't happen often or regularly making conception very difficult.  Many women also take clomid when trying to conceive with PCOS (stimulates ovulation/egg release).  PCOS is not uncommon and I've had many friends with it.  Most have gone on to have families!  Yes, those side effects of the condition are a bear for a woman---  who wants facial hair and weight gain??!!!  My dear friend really struggled with this--  the metformin really did help.  so, give this time to work.Now, Med Help Is wonderful!!  We have a PCOS forum.  Here is the link:http://www.medhelp.org/forums/Polycystic-Ovarian-Syndrome-PCOS/show/203Here is an excellent source for information on this as well.  It's from the govt.'s site for women's health.http://womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/polycystic-ovary-syndrome.htmlI wish you lots of luck and we are here if you need more information or support.  There are women here that you can connect with that also have PCOS.  good luck and peace

question: Hi, I am 21 years old and my husband and I are talking about trying to have a baby in the near future. Over the last 2 years or so my normal doctor and my obgyn have talked about the possibility of my having PCOS. Last month I was officially diagnosed. That day I was put on Metformin. I take that twice a die, even though I am not diabetic yet, she explained to me that I am very likely to become a diabetic soon due to my strong family history on both my mother's and father's side. I started weight watchers a few days after my visit and have been exercising regularly. As most women with this condition I have EXTREMELY irregular periods. I always have. I typically never have cramping and if I do it is nothing that I can tolerate. This morning I woke up with excessively heavy bleeding and severe cramps. I called my OBGYN where I was informed their office is closed on Fridays and so I called my General doctor to see what I should do.  They asked me to come in where I then went through a series of test to make sure I wasn't having a miscarriage and to cheap my hemoglobin levels. All of that checked out fine and then I was then put on Norethindrone. This is supposed to stop the bleeding or at least make it normal. With all of this being said, I want to know more information about PCOS. There is no family history of this in my family and I don't know anyone else with it. I ask questions when I am at the doctors office but they don't seem to know much about it either. What are some ways to reduce the side effects. I have hormone imbalance, excess hair growth, difficulty with weight loss along with most of the other common symptoms. I don't have any cysts which at first caused me to believe that I didn't actually have the disease. From what I have read and learned you don't have to have cysts to have the disease so the name can be misleading, is this correct? I am basically just looking for any information that you have to offer.
title: Recently diagnosed with PCOS
